_meta.note: Readable lore content for Guard's Journal Pages, Quest Notices, Training Manual Pages, and other narrative items. Updated for more grounded, Bethesda-style storytelling.

guards_journal_pages.text: Eastern wall showing cracks. Captain Merris ordered double watch rotation. Men are tired. Rations down to two-thirds portion. Some talk of heading back to the surface, but desertion means a flogging if caught. Better hungry than bleeding.

Supply cart didn't arrive this week. Found tracks near the grain stores - looks like rats got in through the drainage grate. Thompson's fixing it tomorrow. Haven't heard from the lower garrison in three days. Their messenger pigeon came back with no note attached.

New posting came through. They're rotating me to the eastern passages next week. Jenkins says the air's bad down there - makes you light-headed. He was stationed there last month and came back saying he couldn't remember the shift. Doctor says it's just fatigue.

Training the new recruits today. Most are farmers' sons, never held a sword before. Gave them the usual warnings about checking corners and watching their backs in the narrow corridors. Half probably won't make it past their first real patrol. We'll know which ones have the sense to survive by week's end.

Something came through the sealed passage in sector 7 last night. Left tracks in the dust - looked human, but Sergeant Hale says the stride length was all wrong. We resealed it with extra mortar this morning. Captain wants armed watch on it for the next month.

Heard strange sounds from the old chapel wing - almost like singing, but distant. Sent three guards to investigate. They came back saying the acoustics down there play tricks. Wind through the broken windows, probably. Still, we're avoiding that section for now. No reason to risk it.

Cold's getting worse in the lower levels. Ice forming on the walls even though we're well below freezing point elevation. Miller got frostbite on his hands during patrol. Quartermaster requisitioned more warm gear from the surface, but it'll be two weeks before it arrives.

Found this journal entry in my pack. Don't remember writing it, but the handwriting looks like mine. Says to avoid the bell tower on the 15th. Not sure what month. Probably just got drunk and wrote nonsense. Bell tower's been condemned anyway.

Someone broke into the armory last night. Nothing stolen, but all the weapons were rearranged. Swords face outward now instead of inward. Captain thinks it's a prank from the night shift. Lock's being replaced tomorrow.

Hayes keeps insisting the statue in the courtyard has moved. Says it used to face east and now faces west. I checked the installation records - it's always faced west. Marcus agrees with Hayes though. Going to report this to the captain. Might be stress.

Mess hall served mushroom stew tonight. Thompson said it tasted different than usual. Williams mentioned his grandmother used to make something similar. Got me thinking about home. Haven't seen my family in six months. Need to write them a letter.

North gallery ceiling collapsed today. Managed to dig out most of the guards trapped below. Seven injuries, no casualties thankfully. Found some old bones in the rubble though - probably from when this place was first built. Going to seal off that section.

Anderson and I got separated during our patrol of the eastern wing. Took me an hour to find him - turns out he'd been following what he thought was my torch light. We were walking in parallel corridors the whole time. The layout down there is confusing. Need better maps.

Found a locked chest in the old barracks. No key, but there was one in my quarters that fit. Inside were some old assignment papers. Looks like someone was scheduled for a post that never got built. Probably from when they were still planning expansions down here.

Someone's been tending the flowers in Captain Aldric's old quarters. Didn't realize anyone still went in there - he transferred out two years ago. Flowers are red primrose. Smell reminds me of pipe tobacco. Will ask around about who's maintaining the room.

Being reassigned next month to the restricted sectors. Special duty - they call it the Silent Watch. Less talking, more listening apparently. Long shifts. Good pay increase though. Need to clear out my locker and hand over my current post duties to Williams.

quest_notices.title: WANTED: Thief in Cathedral District
quest_notices.text: Recent thefts from the Glasswork Cathedral. Suspect leaves no obvious entry points. Several valuable crystal pieces missing. Witness reports are inconsistent. Contact Temple Guard if you have information. Approach suspect with caution if located.

quest_notices.title: URGENT: Retrieve Blade from Vault
quest_notices.text: The ceremonial sword known as 'The Singing Blade' was misplaced in the Harmony Vault during inventory three years ago. Staff report hearing metallic resonance from the sealed section during certain moon phases. Need recovered for upcoming ceremony. Vault key available at administration.

quest_notices.title: CONTRACT: Archive Restoration
quest_notices.text: Lower archives flooded during spring thaw. Water damage to historical records. Some documents appear to have bled into others - need separation and restoration. Priority: military records, census data, land deeds. Report to Chief Archivist Pemberton for details.

quest_notices.title: BOUNTY: Decommission Malfunctioning Construct
quest_notices.text: Clockwork patrol unit #47 continues operating despite shutdown order. Last serviced 40 years ago. Internal timer appears stuck. Continues patrol route through now-residential areas. Causes disturbances at night. Salvage parts after deactivation. Tools provided.

quest_notices.title: EXPEDITION: Map Eastern Corridors
quest_notices.text: Eastern wing layout keeps changing due to structural settling. Need updated floor plans for resource allocation. Previous survey teams submitted conflicting data - possibly working from outdated base maps. Surveying equipment available. Report discrepancies to Master Builder Carlson.

quest_notices.title: EMERGENCY: Bell Tower Repairs
quest_notices.text: Prayer bells in the Sunken Oratory malfunction at midnight - ringing in reverse sequence. Residents report sleep disturbances and disorientation. Mechanism likely needs oil and realignment. Access through west stairwell. Bring standard climbing gear.

quest_notices.title: COMMISSION: Portrait Recovery
quest_notices.text: Family portrait of Lady Ashdown needs retrieval from Crimson Gallery. Frame possibly water-damaged - appears to be weeping condensation. Gallery is in restricted wing but family has obtained access permits. Portrait is large, will need two people for safe transport.

quest_notices.title: ALERT: Chamber Acoustics Issue
quest_notices.text: Echo Chamber in Resonance Wing experiencing feedback loops. Possibly due to water in the walls creating unexpected sound reflection. Recordings of conversations from previous use are playing back at random intervals. Need acoustic engineer to assess and repair.

quest_notices.title: POSTING: Apprentice for Artifact Studies
quest_notices.text: Scholar Whitmore seeking assistant for supernatural artifact research. Previous apprentice transferred to different department. Duties include cataloging, documentation, and basic warding rituals. No experience necessary. Housing provided in research wing.

quest_notices.title: REQUEST: Locate Missing Explorer
quest_notices.text: Merchant's daughter Elisa entered the dungeon six months ago. Last known location: eastern passages near the old mining sector. Has been sending letters but return address is unclear. Family desperate for contact. Knows the area well but may be lost or injured.

quest_notices.title: DANGER: Structural Warning - Gilt Hall
quest_notices.text: The Gilt Hall on sublevel three is unsafe for entry. Gold leaf coating on walls is flaking badly. Samples show unusual chemical composition - possibly toxic. Area sealed until further notice. Contact site foreman before attempting any maintenance work.

quest_notices.title: INVESTIGATION: Spatial Anomaly - South Wing
quest_notices.text: South wing floor plan does not match architectural blueprints. Measurements show discrepancies of 10-15 feet in several corridors. Need surveyor to remeasure and update building records. May be due to poor record keeping or unmapped renovations from previous century.

quest_notices.title: NOTICE: Guard Recruitment Drive
quest_notices.text: Dungeon Security needs additional personnel for eastern wing patrols. Experience preferred but will train motivated candidates. Must pass physical examination and background check. Long shifts in underground environment. Apply at garrison headquarters. Reference code: EAST-147.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 3: Footwork Fundamentals
training_manual_pages.text: A warrior's foundation comes from proper footwork. The Shifting Tiles exercise teaches balance adaptation on uneven surfaces. Recommended for all recruits. Some tiles in the training hall are intentionally loosened - teaches awareness of unstable ground common in older dungeon sections.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 7: Combat Awareness
training_manual_pages.text: In close quarters combat, watch for unusual breathing patterns in opponents - indicates fatigue or fear. Check shadows for additional assailants. Be wary of opponents with strange injury patterns - could indicate they're disease carriers or have unusual pain tolerance.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 11: Survival Protocols
training_manual_pages.text: Three rules for dungeon survival: 1) Don't eat preserved food older than one season - risk of spoilage. 2) Don't enter chambers where the door frame shows forced entry - structural integrity questionable. 3) Don't follow voices you can't see the source of - acoustic tricks common in older sections.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 15: Mental Fortitude
training_manual_pages.text: Long periods underground can cause disorientation. Keep a calendar. Mark your route. If you experience hallucinations, report to medical staff immediately - could be carbon monoxide from bad ventilation. The Void Halls have particularly poor air quality - travel through quickly.

training_manual_pages.title: Appendix C: Emergency Procedures
training_manual_pages.text: If alarm bells sound thirteen times, proceed to designated safe zones - indicates structural failure above. Avoid doors marked with red paint - these seal plague quarantine areas from old outbreaks. Report strange odors to maintenance - could indicate corpse flowers, which bloom near decomposing organic matter.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 5: Weapon Maintenance
training_manual_pages.text: Clean your blade after every use. Blood causes rust, and rust causes blade failure. Weapons used frequently may develop stress fractures - examine weekly. Blades that seem to cut unevenly may have developed microscopic damage. Replace before critical failure occurs.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 9: Formation Fighting
training_manual_pages.text: Shield wall drills require coordination and trust. Maintain proper spacing - gaps create vulnerabilities. If formation breaks, regroup at designated rally point. Practice these drills regularly. Muscle memory saves lives when you can't think clearly under stress.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 13: Armor Care
training_manual_pages.text: Inspect armor daily for rust, cracks, and wear patterns. Dungeon humidity accelerates metal degradation. Unusual markings may indicate exposure to acidic substances - common near certain fungi. Strange patterns could also be mold growth in leather bindings. Clean thoroughly.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 19: Advanced Techniques - PAGES MISSING
training_manual_pages.text: The Seven Forms series. Forms one through three cover basic strike patterns. Forms four through six are detailed in the sealed archives - restricted training requires instructor supervision. Form seven is theoretical and not recommended for practical application due to injury risk.

training_manual_pages.title: Appendix F: Supernatural Encounters
training_manual_pages.text: When dealing with reported supernatural events: Document everything. Check for natural explanations first - gas leaks, mold spores, carbon monoxide all cause hallucinations. If phenomena persists, contact the ecclesiastical department. They maintain records of genuine anomalies versus environmental issues.

scrawled_notes.text: Day 3: Found a shortcut through the wine cellar. Day 4: Used it again, definitely faster. Day 5: Took longer than expected today, maybe I got turned around. Day 6: Pretty sure I took the same route but ended up somewhere different. Day 7: Getting my map redrawn.

There's a merchant in the west hall who sells old keepsakes. Got a locket yesterday that reminded me of my childhood. Weird how certain objects bring back memories so vividly. Paid good coin for it. Been going back for more. Starting to forget why I came here. But the memories are nice.

WARNING to maintenance crews: The woman in corridor 7 offering to guide people is not staff. She's wearing old uniform from decades ago. Probably just confused. Directs people to wrong locations. Ignore her and use your maps. Some of the older timers remember her from service but she should've retired years ago.

Been marking days on my wall. Today noticed some marks are crossed out - only the Thursday marks. Don't remember crossing them out. Roommate says I do it in my sleep sometimes. Should probably get more rest. Haven't been sleeping well lately.

Found a room full of mirrors today. My reflection seemed to move oddly - probably just cheap mirrors with warped glass. Thompson mentioned he saw the same thing. We're avoiding that room. The light is bad in there anyway. Makes you dizzy.

NOTICE: The stairwell to lower levels only opens on Tuesdays - mechanical lock issue. Maintenance working on it. If you get stuck in the stairwell when it closes, there's an emergency bell pull on the third landing. Wait for rescue crew.

The paintings in the portrait gallery need cleaning. The subjects look different through all the dust and grime. Several frames are empty - paintings probably removed for restoration. One appeared to be gone yesterday but was back this morning. Need to check with curator.

Tried wishing at the fountain in the south courtyard - old tradition apparently. Tossed in a coin. Interesting place. Old architecture. Makes you think about the people who built this place. What they must have been like. What they wanted. Got distracted and lost an hour just thinking.

Found a chess set in the abandoned barracks. Pieces are positioned mid-game. Must've been someone's game from years ago. Left it as is - seems disrespectful to disturb it. Though I swear the pieces have moved slightly each time I've walked past. Probably just vibration from foot traffic.

List of good patrol routes: Library wing (quieter during weekdays). Kitchen area (always warm, good for breaks). Barracks section (well-lit). Avoid the mirror hall - poor visibility. This list is from old guard manual. Someone added notes in margin - can't read the handwriting but seems like good advice.

pressed_pages.text: From 'The Botanical Treatise': The thornvines in the deep archives show unusual growth patterns - possibly carnivorous based on trap-like leaves. They've been there for centuries according to records. Interesting how they've adapted to the low-light environment. Study samples need approval from head botanist.

Catalog entry 447-B: The red flowers in the Thorn Archive produce interesting harmonies when disturbed by airflow. Musical qualities documented. Care requirements include regular watering schedule and occasional fertilization. Blood meal fertilizer produces strongest blooms - standard for this species.

Research log, Dr. Holloway: The pressed page collection in the archives contains remarkable historical specimens. Some species no longer grow in this region. Several samples are from books destroyed in the great fire. My assistant Merchant mentioned finding pages that aren't in our catalog. Will need to cross-reference with the historical database.

Entry from Botanist's Journal: Specimen 47 - Red petals, unknown species from northern gardens. Exhibits unusual growth rate - three times normal. After three months, specimen has spread to seven pots. Root structure suggests aggressive colonization behavior. May need to limit to isolated greenhouse.

Letter fragment pressed into page: '...having trouble finding the way back. These corridors all look the same. Mother, if you find this, I may be late getting home. The exit signs are confusing. I've been walking in circles. Three others are lost too. We're staying together for now...'

Recipe card, corners burnt: 'Dungeon Bread: Use stone-ground flour from the eastern mill. Add spring water. Knead for three hours minimum. Bake until golden brown. Cooking time varies by oven temperature. Makes excellent field rations. Bread stays fresh for weeks if properly stored.'

surgeons_notes.text: Patient 23: Unusual symptoms - dust inhalation from Alabaster Ward. Lung irritation, mild calcification of extremities. Probably silica exposure. Treatment: rest, fluids, steam therapy. Patient reports feeling 'heavy' - likely fluid retention. Monitor for pneumonia. Prognosis good with proper rest.

Medical observation: The dust in the Alabaster Ward has high mineral content - likely pulverized limestone from old construction. Prolonged exposure causes respiratory issues. Recommend masks for anyone working in that area. Several cases of chronic cough reported. Improved ventilation needed.

Autopsy report: Patient deceased from advanced lung disease. Years of dust exposure in the quarry district. Significant calcification in lung tissue. Recommend better safety equipment for workers. Patient's final words indicated difficulty breathing - consistent with obstruction. Recommend improved dust control protocols.

Surgical log, Dr. Vance: Attempted to remove crystalline growths from Patient 89. Formations are calcium deposits, possibly from mineral-rich water. Patient conscious and talkative during procedure - said she's been drinking from the eastern wells. Those wells need testing. Growth rate concerning.

Case study: Several cases of severe dermatitis in workers from the Marble Gallery. Skin hardens over time - possibly due to chemical exposure from cleaning agents used on the stone. Recommend protective gear. Condition progresses slowly - early cases show full recovery with proper treatment and job rotation.

Medical transcript: 'Doctor, I've been experiencing synesthesia lately. Colors seem to have tastes. It's disorienting. I work in the dye district - possibly exposure to the chemicals. Blue dye in particular has a strong smell. The purple dye makes me nauseous. Need to switch departments for a while.'

puzzle_notes.text: The Riddle Mill's mechanism was designed by Engineer Cogworth. Complex gear system powers the grinding stones. Original purpose was grain milling. Now used as training puzzle for recruits. The machinery makes unsettling sounds - probably needs oil. The flour it produces is for demonstration only, not consumption.

Solution to Millstone Puzzle: Turn wheel counter-clockwise three times. Answer prompt requires knowledge of local history. Final step involves placing token in slot. Puzzle rewards are purely ceremonial. Note: Mechanism is old and temperamental. Follow instructions exactly or it may jam.

Lock Mechanism Treatise: The combination lock in the vault uses advanced mathematics. Each digit is based on sequential problem solving. Created by master locksmith Klaus Svensson. Digit 47 requires understanding of complex geometry. Most people get stuck around digit 83. Instruction manual available in security office.

Cipher key found in Archive: Encrypted texts use substitution cipher. Each symbol represents a word or concept rather than letter. Decoding requires cross-referencing with the master lexicon. Most decoded texts are old administrative records. Fascinating look at how the dungeon was organized centuries ago.

star_charts.text: Astronomical notation: The reflected stars in the Stargazer's Pool show unusual patterns. They don't match current night sky - possibly due to the angle and underground positioning. Scholar Hale spent years studying the phenomenon. His notes indicate the reflections show seasonal star patterns from different months. Optical illusion, probably.

Navigation chart: The stars in the underground planetarium are painted markers showing safe routes through dungeon. Red star indicates treasure vaults. North star points to surface exit. Black marks show dangerous areas. Standard dungeon navigation system from the old days. Still useful if you know how to read it.

Celestial observations, Dr. Vess: The constellation painted on the courtyard ceiling rotates slowly - mechanical device built into the roof. Cycles through twelve positions representing months. Paint has faded making it hard to read. The text describes safe travel times through various seasons. Need restoration work done.

Star map fragment: The wandering light that appears during solstices is actually a reflected torch from the upper level guardian's tower. Creates interesting optical effect through the shaft. Old legend says wishing on it brings luck. Mostly just tradition now. Still, harmless fun for the recruits.

cracked_map_scraps.text: Partial dungeon map, water-damaged. Shows three corridors that connect oddly - probably due to multiple renovation phases over the centuries. 'You Are Here' mark looks like someone's personal notation. Handwriting in margins doesn't match the printed text. Previous owner's notes, maybe from a guard who worked here.

Fragment of dungeon chart. The scale changes because multiple maps were spliced together - different surveyors used different measurements. Some sections in ink, others in charcoal. One corner has note: 'Surveyed in darkness due to broken lantern. Measurements approximate. Need to redo this section.'

Torn floor plan section. Rooms labeled with warnings: 'Singing Walls - echo chamber', 'Backwards Door - hinges on wrong side', 'Mirror Hall - poor lighting'. Last room says 'Safe Room' with question marks. Someone crossed out 'Safe' and wrote 'Needs Inspection' - probably found structural issues.

Crude map scratched on parchment. The compass rose has five directions marked - whoever drew this was probably confused about orientation. Dotted line traces a route that loops back. Bottom reads: 'Walked for three days surveying. Got turned around. Some rooms look identical. Need better landmarks. Don't trust my counting.'

Explorer's map scrap. Rooms marked with symbols - skulls for danger, hourglasses for time-sensitive tasks, chains for locked areas. Doesn't match what I've found but map is decades old. Things change. Note on edge: 'Map becomes outdated quickly. Renovations constant. Double-check any route before committing.'

Architect's blueprint, heavily worn. The dungeon was designed with experimental geometry - architect wanted to maximize space usage. Some corridors intersect at odd angles. Staircase placement is unconventional. Architect's note: 'Client wanted maximum capacity in limited space. Design pushes structural limits. Recommend regular inspections.'

Survey from Cartographer's Guild: Discrepancy report - measurements don't match between survey teams. Possibly due to equipment calibration differences. Some teams report 47 floors, others report 4 major levels with sub-levels. Need standardized measurement protocol. Lead cartographer retired after project. Recommend resurvey with modern equipment.

Treasure map marked with X. 'Dig here' it says. Looks like a prank - someone doodling on official survey maps. Multiple X marks all over. Some bored guard probably drew this during a slow shift. Found similar joke maps in the archives. People get creative during long assignments.

Topographical map with elevation markers. Shows odd readings - Level 1 at sea level, Level 2 somehow reads higher despite being underground. Probably equipment malfunction during survey. Previous surveyor noted discrepancies. Recommend new survey with calibrated instruments. These old readings are unreliable.

Hand-drawn map on parchment. Routes marked in different colors. 'Echo Corridor' noted for acoustic issues. 'Silent Hall' requires quiet for some reason. 'Forgetting Path' - probably just a nickname, maybe officers called it that because it was forgettable. Center shows 'Administration Office'. Standard layout notation.

old_letters.text: Dear Elena, I'm writing to let you know I arrived safely at my new post. The dungeon guard work is harder than expected. Corridors all look similar and I keep getting turned around. But the pay is good and I'm getting used to it. Think of you often. Will write again next week. -Marcus

To my family: Made it to the dungeon looking for work. Found employment with the mining crew. Pay is better than farmwork back home. Food isn't great but beats being hungry. Miss everyone. Will send money home when I can. Tell mother I'm eating well. -Your son

Father, I'm sorry I left without saying goodbye. The debt collectors were getting aggressive and I didn't want trouble to reach the family. Took work in the dungeon - dangerous but pays well. Should have enough to clear the debt in a few months. Will write when I can. -Thomas

Dear Brother, expedition is going well so far. Captain Morris seems competent. We've mapped about half the eastern wing. Some areas are unstable - old construction settling. Planning to finish survey next week and head back. Food supplies holding up. See you soon. -William

Dearest Sarah, you were right about this being dangerous work. Had close call yesterday - ceiling collapse in the north passage. No one hurt thankfully. Makes you appreciate solid ground. Contract is for six more months then I'm coming home. We'll have enough saved for the house by then. -Jonathan

To the Warden: I'm requesting transfer to different section. Current assignment has me rotating through too many areas and I keep losing track of where I'm supposed to be. Would prefer stable posting in one wing. Getting disoriented by constant route changes. Please consider. -Previous Guard Captain

My beloved, your letter from last month finally reached me. Mail delivery down here is slow. I'm doing well, just tired. Long shifts. The work is monotonous but safe enough if you follow procedures. Counting the days until I can come home. Miss you. -Marcus

Brother Augustine, the monastery was correct that this place tests one's faith. Lots of time alone with your thoughts down here. The isolation is challenging. I've been keeping prayer journals. Helps maintain perspective. Will finish my service contract and return to the order soon. -Brother Thomas

To my future self: Remember to bring better boots next assignment. The stone floors are hell on feet. Also, bring more lamp oil. They never give you enough. Map out your routes early. Don't rely on signage - half of it is outdated. Trust the senior guards. They know the real layout.

My daughter, by the time you read this I'll have been working in the dungeon for twenty years. Time passes strangely down here - days blend together. I kept this journal so I wouldn't forget why I came. The pay let us afford your schooling. Worth every hour. Coming home soon. -Papa

Dear Reader, I hid my personal savings in the dungeon before retiring - old guard tradition. Left clues for my family to find it. Seemed like fun at the time. Now I realize how confusing the layout is. If you're reading this and you find coins, they're probably mine. Consider it a lucky find. -Retired Guard Hadley

To the Explorer's Guild: I'm resigning from dungeon guide service. After fifteen years I need a change. The work is repetitive and the lack of sunlight is affecting my health. Thank you for the opportunity. Will help train my replacement before leaving. Best wishes. -Guild Master Petra

prayer_strips.text: Prayer for Safe Travel: 'May the path be clear and the journey swift.' Traditional blessing recited by guards before patrol. Simple ritual. Morale booster more than anything. Old tradition from when the dungeon first opened. Still practiced by some of the older staff.

Blessing of Safe Passage: 'Guide us straight and true.' Short prayer often carved into lintels above doorways. Architectural tradition from the builders. Similar carvings found throughout the older sections. Provides sense of continuity with the past.

Rite of Remembrance: 'Honor those who came before.' Memorial service held monthly for guards who've retired or passed away. List of names read aloud. Dignified ceremony. Names engraved on memorial wall in the main hall. Good for morale to remember our history.

Invocation of Protection: 'Shield us from harm, guide us from danger, bring us home safely.' Standard prayer recited at start of shift. Like a soldier's oath. Reminds everyone to watch out for each other. Simple but effective for team cohesion.

Litany of Clarity: 'Grant us clear sight and clear mind.' Popular among scholars and researchers. Helps focus before long study sessions. Also used by guards for maintaining alertness during boring overnight shifts. Common enough to be almost a secular tradition now.

Hymn of the Depths: 'From darkness to darkness, in darkness we work.' Sung by the old mining crews. Melancholy but honest about the working conditions. Tradition carried on by some of the veteran staff. Reminds us we're all in this together, working in the dark.

Supplication for Mercy: 'We are small and weak before great forces. Remember our humanity.' Used in formal religious ceremonies. Humility prayer. Standard in most traditional faiths. Written in old language but translated versions are common.

Chant of Unseeing: 'What we overlook holds no power over us.' Meditation mantra used by some guards to deal with stress. Philosophy being that overthinking dangers makes them worse. Focus on the work at hand, don't imagine problems that aren't there. Practical approach.

Prayer of Last Resort: 'When all hope fails, when all paths close, when darkness falls, we call uponâ€”' Text is damaged. Last line missing. Old prayer probably from the founding era. Academic interest only. Most guards prefer simpler, complete prayers.

Devotional of the Endless Vigil: 'We watch, we guard, we maintain.' Motto of the Silent Watch - elite guard unit that handles restricted areas. They take vows of minimal speaking to maintain focus. Serious about security. Respected but considered a bit extreme by regular staff.
